media:group.media:title: Armenian parliament targets opposition lawmakers
media:group.media:description:
๐ Armeniaโs parliament debates lifting immunity for opposition lawmakers Seyran Ohanyan and Artsvik Minasyan over corruption-related charges. ๐ Detained businessman Samvel Karapetyan is suing two ruling party lawmakers for defamation over claims linking him to Russia and activity against the state. ๐ The Armenian Patriarch of Istanbul explains the Patriarchateโs closure during Pashinyanโs visit last month, citing procedural issues and a silent protest over the prime ministerโs criticism of the Catholicos.

entry.title: Can Azerbaijan be prosecuted for war crimes?

media:group.media:title: Can Azerbaijan be prosecuted for war crimes?
media:group.media:description:
Steve Swerdlow, human rights lawyer and professor at the University of Southern California, examines the human rights implications of Azerbaijanโs 2022 attack on Armenia and the ongoing border aggression. Drawing on international law and his own fieldwork, Swerdlow argues that these actions constitute a crime, and calls for accountability through the International Criminal Court or universal jurisdiction, a legal principle that allows states or international organizations to prosecute individuals. He also highlights the dangers of entrenched hate speech and Armenophobia in Azerbaijan, and makes the case for international pressure, legal action, and a recommitment by Armenia to its human rights obligations as part of its path forward.
0:00- Introduction 0:34- Azerbaijanโs September 2022 invasion of Armenia 2:41- The crime of aggression 4:29- Azerbaijan will be held to account 5:23- Will Azerbaijan dodge international accountability forever? 8:46- Effects of hatred being inculcated into Azerbaijani society 11:51- Importance of Armenia upholding democratic principles

entry.title: Whatโs really behind Armeniaโs alleged insurrection?

media:group.media:description:
In this episode of _Insights_ , host Eric Hacopian covers the arrest of Archbishop Ajapahyan and the deeper implications of the alleged coup plot. Additionally, Hacopian takes a look at the shameful rhetoric dominating Armenian politics, and what it reveals about the country's direction.
